_meta.note: Infamous packages that triggered supply chain incidents

left-pad.description: 11-line package that broke the internet when unpublished from npm
roasts: left-pad detected. The 11 lines of code that taught npm about trust issues.
Ah, left-pad. The package that proved the entire JavaScript ecosystem depended on string padding.
left-pad survivor detected. March 22, 2016. Never forget.
You have left-pad in your ancestry. The trauma is hereditary.

event-stream.description: Maintainer handed over to attacker who injected cryptocurrency miner
roasts: event-stream found. The package that showed us what 'supply chain attack' really means.
I see event-stream. Hope you weren't holding any Bitcoin in 2018.
event-stream: When 'I'll maintain this for you' became 'I'll mine crypto for me'.
The event-stream incident: A cautionary tale about npm trust.

colors.description: Maintainer intentionally broke the package to protest unpaid open source work
roasts: colors detected. Remember when it started printing LIBERTY LIBERTY LIBERTY?
The colors incident: When a maintainer had enough of working for free.
colors: The package that turned console output into a political statement.
I see colors. The package that proved maintainer burnout is a security issue.

faker.description: Same maintainer as colors, deleted code and replaced with 'endgame' message
roasts: faker found. Another casualty of the great npm meltdown of 2022.
The faker incident taught us all about single maintainer risk.
faker: When 'fake data generator' became 'real problems generator'.
I see faker. The package that faked its own death.

ua-parser-js.description: Maintainer account compromised, malicious versions published with crypto miner
roasts: ua-parser-js detected. The 2021 supply chain attack classic.
Remember when ua-parser-js shipped a cryptocurrency miner? Good times.
ua-parser-js: Parsing user agents AND mining cryptocurrency since 2021.
I see ua-parser-js. Hope you checked which version you have.

node-ipc.description: Maintainer added code to wipe files on Russian/Belarusian systems as Ukraine protest
roasts: node-ipc detected. The package that turned 'npm install' into geopolitical warfare.
node-ipc: When your build process becomes a political statement.
I see node-ipc. The package that proved dependencies can be weapons.
node-ipc: Protesting war by attacking computers. What could go wrong?

flatmap-stream.description: Malicious package injected into event-stream dependency chain
roasts: flatmap-stream found. The actual malware in the event-stream incident.
flatmap-stream: The package that was literally designed to steal Bitcoin.
I see flatmap-stream. This is the payload, not the victim.
flatmap-stream: When 'dependency' means 'backdoor'.

eslint-scope.description: Maintainer credentials stolen, malicious version published
roasts: eslint-scope detected. npm credentials on pastebin, classic.
eslint-scope: The package that taught us about 2FA.
I see eslint-scope. Another credential stuffing victim.
eslint-scope incident: When 'password123' meets supply chain.

is-promise.description: Innocent update broke thousands of packages due to ES module export
roasts: is-promise found. The 2-line package that broke the world. Again.
is-promise: Proof that even tiny packages can cause massive outages.
I see is-promise. Another 'it's just a few lines' incident.
is-promise: Breaking builds since 2020 with just 2 lines of code.

crossenv.description: Typosquat of cross-env that stole environment variables
roasts: crossenv detected. The typosquat that taught us to read package names.
crossenv: It's cross-env with a dash. THE DASH MATTERS.
I see crossenv. Did you mean cross-env? Because attackers hoped you didn't.
crossenv: Typosquatting 101.

lodahs.description: Typosquat of lodash designed to steal credentials
roasts: lodahs detected. LODAHS. Not LODASH. Read it again.
I see lodahs. The typosquat that preyed on fast typists.
lodahs: When autocomplete fails you and attackers win.
lodahs detected. Spell check your dependencies, people.
